68695245BC8541E5A907D9F7AA665E0A.description: Use newly acquired domain-specific words and phrases accurately.

545A4C44C9D949ECA3841B7309E9BA9A.description: Use grade appropriate general academic and domain-specific words and phrases accurately within writing.

84A761B3ACBD4F75926BC9F2E354A31E.description:
Acquire and use accurately general academic and domain-specific words and phrases, sufficient for reading, writing, speaking, and listening at
the college and career readiness level; demonstrate independence in gathering vocabulary knowledge when considering a word or phrase
important to comprehension or expression.

B97318A10CF34790918105EF3350DB1C.description: Explain differences or changes in the meaning of words with similar denotations.

E382AA73D47A48A4AFC85878C6280D95.description: Interpret figures of speech in context.

D7A9CB01CBF343A79067176670F4E6F2.description: Interpret how literary devices advance the plot, affect the tone or pacing of a work.

E52178DBF08C4577A7A91995FD6E420E.description: Identify the denotation for a known word.

A3628F8DB4DA4331A86D3FF6207286C4.description: Identify an oxymoron in a text.

F5745A765A3245B8B650930D84F21BD3.description:
Demonstrate understanding of figurative language, word relationships, and nuances in word meanings.
a. Interpret figures of speech (e.g., euphemism, oxymoron) in context and analyze their role in the text.
b. Analyze nuances in the meaning of words with similar denotations.

3845D2027539414DB152337EAB150876.description: Verify the prediction of the meaning of a new word or phrase (e.g., by checking a dictionary).

10479430DEBB4962A59C6E0F533A6D5E.description: Consult reference materials (e.g., dictionaries, glossaries, thesauruses) to find the part of speech for a word.

CAFC1DB80715449A871BBA40DF4AA80C.description: Consult reference materials (e.g., dictionaries, glossaries, thesauruses) to find the precise meaning of a word.

77B300C1DBA546B9B032182C46D0F5DC.description: Consult reference materials (e.g., dictionaries, glossaries, thesauruses) to find the synonym for a word.

03E7D683E6E14347A96C6A00964AE716.description:
Use context (e.g., the overall meaning of a sentence, paragraph, or text; a word's position in a sentence) as a clue to the
meaning of a word or phrase.

BC24DE3E4C6648E89AF0162754EF42FF.description:
Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases based on grades 9–10 reading and content, choosing
flexibly from a range of strategies.
a. Identify and correctly use patterns of word changes that indicate different meanings or parts of speech (e.g., analyze, analysis, analytical;
advocate, advocacy).
b. Use context (e.g., the overall meaning of a sentence, paragraph, or text; a word’s position or function in a sentence) as a clue to the meaning
of a word or phrase.
c. Consult general and specialized reference materials (e.g., dictionaries, glossaries, thesauruses), both print and digital, to find the
pronunciation of a word or determine or clarify its precise meaning, its part of speech, or its etymology.
d. Verify the preliminary determination of the meaning of a word or phrase.

3C38E0722DCC447C8D06F517D7B9B3E2.description: Write and edit work to conform to guidelines in a style manual.

889D56BDA8214A0C9BB71D84F78A1A7A.description:
Apply knowledge of language to understand how language functions in different contexts, to make effective choices for meaning or style, and
to comprehend more fully when reading or listening.
a. Write and edit work so that it conforms to the guidelines in a style manual.

6FA8A37A83784C13BCD5EB8EF2C07BF5.description:
Use a semicolon (i.e., link two or more related independent clauses) and/or colon (i.e., to introduce a list or quotation)
appropriately in writing.

B5DA3F44AB614428BD2D999FD03D93E9.description:
Demonstrate command of the conventions of Standard English capitalization, punctuation, and spelling when writing.
a. Use a semicolon (and perhaps a conjunctive adverb) to link two or more closely related independent clauses.
b. Use a colon to introduce a list or quotation.
c. Use correct spelling.

EF46D4C934D6485691E3145842A1CE5A.description:
Use various types of phrases (noun, verb, adjectival, adverbial, participial, prepositional, absolute) and clauses
(independent, dependent; noun, relative, adverbial) to convey meaning and add interest to writing.

F86E2627BB5144068E61EF10E238CB88.description: Use parallel structure (e.g., when using gerunds [-ing], infinitives, or voice [active or passive]) within writing.

C27943A8FCEE4582A36D00AB907109C6.description:
Demonstrate command of the conventions of Standard English grammar and usage when writing or speaking.
a. Use parallel structure.
b. Use various types of phrases (noun, verb, adjectival, adverbial, participial, prepositional, and absolute) and clauses (independent,
dependent; noun, relative, adverbial) to convey specific meanings and add variety and interest to writing or presentations.

24A9793D28F44318A3537025A79732D1.description: No CCCs written for this standard.

6966EDC0E8794450909B12DB9F2EF90B.description:
Adapt speech to a variety of contexts and tasks, demonstrating command of formal English when indicated or appropriate. (See grades 9–10
Language standards 1 and 3 for specific expectations.)

EB0D6BE1FC03456B8EC2CF232949078E.description:
Include digital or multimedia components and visual displays in presentations to clarify claims and findings and emphasize
salient points.

5D973E5C20764A12BD4DC4F2AC9DBACF.description: Make strategic use of digital media in presentations to enhance understanding of findings, reasoning, and evidence and to add interest.

695129F1EE44426186E72DA7AE7C1BB6.description:
Report on a topic, using a logical sequence of ideas, appropriate facts and relevant, and descriptive details which support
the main ideas.

EB9144C702884064AC32FD8D40FC4121.description:
Present information, findings, and supporting evidence clearly, concisely, and logically such that listeners can follow the line of reasoning and
the organization, development, substance, and style are appropriate to purpose, audience, and task; use appropriate eye contact, adequate
volume, and clear pronunciation.

B1CABE2DEBF44AA19C55836476F28A2A.description: Evaluate a speaker's point of view, reasoning, and use of evidence for false statements, faulty reasoning or exaggeration.

748F943C58B64958BB76FBA8FB0A45F7.description: Evaluate the evidence used to make the argument.

F147D04E84CE4DECB7FADE29EAD344A8.description: Determine what arguments the speaker makes.

7348946263F24DA6ABA06E9851A3128B.description: Determine the speaker's point of view or purpose in a text.

5A4825BD1F6349CDBAE645C9CAFB310C.description:
Evaluate a speaker’s point of view, reasoning, use of evidence, and use of rhetoric, identifying any fallacious reasoning or exaggerated or
distorted evidence.

8EF10FCF7F8448E2A21F239F22EBA070.description: Analyze credibility of sources and accuracy of information presented in social media regarding a given topic or text.

39D30D835C55499393933E0610985951.description: Integrate multiple sources of information presented in diverse media and formats, evaluating the credibility and accuracy of each source.

61340E399F1D4FE09EA264D8B0C166DC.description:
Use evidence and reasoning presented in discussion on topic or text to make new connections with own view or
understanding.

ED891B1805AC4CF7AE048C30B33623D0.description: Summarize points of agreement and disagreement within a discussion on a given topic or text.

3DB214EA4B354D9BA0DE472F79DA2A14.description: Clarify, verify, or challenge ideas and conclusions within a discussion on a given topic or text.

24991800689748ECA7AC5E180B716C55.description: Engage appropriately in discussion with others who have a diverse or divergent perspective.

2F9501A7F9254670A28419AE5DC855DC.description: Actively seek the ideas or opinions of others in a discussion on a given topic or text.

E1EBC502D617436DB1F688808F9B42E4.description: Work with peers to set rules for collegial discussions and decision-making.

0B6C5C7CC5E34B54A98FED759CC22AF0.description:
Initiate and participate effectively in a range of collaborative discussions (one‐on‐ one, in groups, and teacher‐led) with diverse
partners on grades 9–10 topics, texts, and issues, building on others' ideas and expressing their own clearly and persuasively.
a. Come to discussions prepared having read and researched material under study; explicitly draw on that preparation by referring
to evidence from texts and other research on the topic or issue to stimulate a thoughtful, well‐ reasoned exchange of ideas.
b. Work with peers to set rules for collegial discussions and decision‐making (e.g., informal consensus, taking votes on key issues,
and presentation of alternate views), clear goals and deadlines, and individual roles as needed.
c. Propel conversations by posing and responding to questions that relate the current discussion to broader themes or larger ideas;
actively incorporate others into the discussion; and clarify, verify, or challenge ideas and conclusions.
d. Respond thoughtfully to diverse perspectives, summarize points of agreement and disagreement, and, when warranted, qualify
or justify their own views and understanding and make new connections based on the evidence and reasoning presented.

4276E646E9BB4BD6833ABB873A3CD871.description: No CCCs developed for this standard.

A48AC429D08F4D679B6BFF19A9FAEFCC.description:
Write routinely over extended time frames (time for research, reflection, and revision) and shorter time frames (a single sitting or a day or two)
for a range of tasks, purposes, and audiences.

14505D2EA0024C73BA89FD6A672F4426.description:
Evaluate an argument within a text to determine if reasoning is valid; reasoning is accurate; evidence is relevant; and
evidence is sufficient.

71973AFCB7124D818F16E4EAFDC35E4C.description: Provide evidence from literary or information texts to support analysis, reflection, and research.

4E36CCFA2F0D435CADA1EE16C569537B.description:
Draw evidence from literary or informational texts to support analysis, reflection, and research.
a. Apply grades 9-10 Reading standards to literature.
b. Apply grades 9-10 Reading standards to informational text and nonfiction.

85CDDDC7BC48479A924435DFC8717416.description: Use a standard format to write citations.

BF18AF1A38CF459FB8B47CDAD338F696.description: Use a standard format to write citations.

2364DA3AB81A44869BAAB17693FF7A38.description: Integrate information presented by others into the writing product while avoiding plagiarism.

D286C8A581F44660B0F4C77CA1FA439D.description: Integrate information presented by others into the writing product while avoiding plagiarism.

101AC34157FB481D931E64D34E1575EC.description: Gather relevant information about the topic or text and stated claim from authoritative print and/or digital sources.

77ED17658474499E9CA51E300C24301F.description:
Gather (e.g., highlight, quote, or paraphrase from source) relevant information about the topic from authoritative print and/or
digital sources.

F0FCF2AA572549839E738D2585BFE0E4.description:
Gather relevant information from multiple authoritative print and digital sources, using advanced searches effectively; assess the usefulness of
each source in answering the research question; integrate information into the text selectively to maintain the flow of ideas, avoiding
plagiarism and following a standard format for citation.

E981BDEA409E4DAFB40A471F1C48A27D.description:
Follow steps to complete a short or sustained research project to build knowledge on a topic or text, answer a question
and/or solve a problem (e.g., determine topic, locating information on a topic, organizing information related to the topic, drafting a
permanent product).

0164E46F9BA34DE4A179FA95F30AF584.description: Research to Build and Present Knowledge

82F14605EF884607B0801DE4847A7452.description:
Use technology to produce and publish writing. (e.g., use internet to gather information, word processing to generate and
collaborate on writing).

DB623F1F9A124908BD60EAB141C2FCC4.description:
Use technology, including the internet, to produce, publish, and update individual or shared writing products, taking advantage of technology's
capacity to link to other information and to display information flexibly and dynamically.

6DC52ED66D7849F09D1D84057EEC3DEA.description: Strengthen writing by revising and editing.

0A196EDEE8394E928089F5DD81BC6D3B.description: Strengthen writing by revising and editing (e.g., review product, strengthening story).

C81DABADA4344E0EA39E2074A28E65DD.description: Strengthen writing by revising and editing.

DFD051D292CC497DB08FC6C360953C68.description:
Develop a plan for writing (e.g., choose a topic, introduce argument topic, develop a claim, develop a counter claim,
conclude argument).

C26EC30A684C4104B76C9EDE4617A6F9.description:
With guidance and support from peers and adults, develop a plan for writing (e.g., choose a topic, introduce story
elements, develop storyline, conclude story).

A2A39D27DC8E4B6EB74D44FE00B80DD4.description:
Develop a plan for writing (e.g., determine the topic, gather information, develop the topic, provide a meaningful conclusion)
focused on a specific purpose and audience.

5917005D70DD41AB841FDF09C50A1DF6.description:
Develop and strengthen writing as needed by planning, revising, editing, rewriting, or trying a new approach, focusing on addressing what is
most significant for a specific purpose and audience. (Editing for conventions should demonstrate command of Language standards 1–3 up to
and including grades 9–10.)

E37C975823664D289A010999BE9C05DB.description:
Produce a clear coherent permanent product that is appropriate to the specific task, purpose (e.g., to persuade), or
audience.

D737C31F8F42403D935996FB406F13FB.description:
Produce a clear coherent permanent product that is appropriate to the specific task, purpose (e.g., to entertain), or
audience.

DE240239EA174A03B8C08F71067916B6.description:
Produce a clear coherent permanent product that is appropriate to the specific task (e.g., topic), purpose (e.g., to inform), or
audience (e.g., reader).

79E8732934E84D068CEA5EF51D5C2CCB.description: Produce clear and coherent writing in which the development, organization, and style are appropriate to task, purpose, and audience. (Gradespecific expectations for writing types are defined in standards 1–3 above.)

BF87602BC2934826AF757AC64B6FCEFB.description:
Provide a conclusion that follows from and reflects on what is experienced, observed, or resolved over the course of the
narrative.

593A4B7865334F95A94077C062035862.description:
Use precise words and phrases, telling details, and sensory language to convey a vivid picture of the experiences, events,
setting, and/or characters.

C766B0002A2D47169B4E08B8768A02B2.description: Create a smooth progression of experiences or events.

DB2D62B6E1E24D55BC921963DC91ACFB.description: Sequence events so that they build on one another to create a coherent whole.

A7B8C7CF0B5043EDBE5C1E937B38BC79.description: Include plot techniques and pacing (e.g., flashback, foreshadowing, suspense) as appropriate in writing.

DA192264FD1F4616831E2972DDD2A33A.description:
Produce a narrative that includes dialogue that advances the plot of theme (e.g., reveals character motivation, feelings,
thoughts, how character has changed perspectives.

F4AD37470ED143A3BD2F44928DED48B6.description: Engage and orient the reader to the narrator and/or characters.

9C9444C1D80045998D17B2EC435D2285.description:
Engage and orient the reader by setting out a problem, situation, or observation, establishing one or multiple point(s) of
view.

3322E50D3C1D47B4A9CD082EE0D61898.description:
Write narratives to develop real or imagined experiences or events using effective technique, well-chosen details, and well-structured event
sequences.
a. Engage and orient the reader by setting out a problem, situation, or observation, establishing one or multiple point(s) of view, and
introducing a narrator and/or characters; create a smooth progression of experiences or events.
b. Use narrative techniques, such as dialogue, pacing, description, reflection, and multiple plot lines, to develop experiences, events, and/or
characters.
c. Use a variety of techniques to sequence events so that they build on one another to create a coherent whole.
d. Use precise words and phrases, relevant descriptive details, and sensory language to convey a vivid picture of the experiences, events,
setting, and/or characters.
e. Provide a conclusion that follows from and reflects on what is experienced, observed, or resolved over the course of the narrative.

E8CDB4BEB71148C88822B829F1081913.description:
Report on a topic, using a logical sequence of ideas, appropriate facts and relevant, and descriptive details which support
the main ideas.

BFC44AA8D0DF470491937ED249D6BEF1.description: Provide a concluding statement or section that follows from and supports the information or explanation presented.

6132BFB4CFFD4B7AA26501D9102EE281.description: Maintain a consistent style and voice throughout writing.

463C36BF2F3F4B8898CFCE254016836C.description: Use precise language and domain-specific vocabulary to manage the complexity of the topic.

05DD7F397E59413D8C93EED556F187E0.description: Use transitional words, phrases, and clauses that connect ideas and create cohesion within writing.

6F90107B1EF147FDAEC81F16D7E92268.description:
Select relevant facts, extended definitions, concrete details, quotations, or other information and examples appropriate for
the audience.

0F87EE1659054A1C886D38059EB88195.description: Write an introduction that clearly previews information to follow.

5ADC109C9EE84A19AB1C8645846DD33E.description:
Create an organizational structure for writing that groups information logically (e.g., cause/effect, compare/contrast,
descriptions and examples), to support paragraph focus.

8F5E8A9A32824DE5A97E92C3ACAA2955.description:
Write informative/explanatory texts to examine and convey complex ideas, concepts, and information clearly and accurately through the
effective selection, organization, and analysis of content.
a. Introduce a topic; organize complex ideas, concepts, and information to make important connections and distinctions; include formatting
(e.g., headings), graphics (e.g., figures, tables), and multimedia when useful to aiding comprehension.
b. Develop the topic with well-chosen, relevant, and sufficient facts, extended definitions, concrete details, quotations, or other information
and examples appropriate to the audience’s knowledge of the topic.
c. Use appropriate and varied transitions to link the major sections of the text, create cohesion, and clarify the relationships among complex
ideas and concepts.
d. Use precise language and domain-specific vocabulary to manage the complexity of the topic.
e. Establish and maintain a formal style and an appropriate tone while attending to the norms and conventions of the discipline in which they
are writing.
f. Provide a concluding statement or section that follows from and supports the information or explanation presented (e.g., articulating
implications or the significance of the topic).

EF39BF018DA445E2962B4BB45DD26A6F.description: Provide a concluding statement or section that supports the argument presented by stating the significance of the claim.

17C8F66D017A4299A506D1D73BFDFCFB.description: Maintain a consistent style and voice throughout writing.

012486F65C584A39859DA546B2F1121C.description: Use words, phrases, and clauses to clarify the relationship among claims, counterclaims, reasons, and evidence.

FE36A87FD7114C3983CCC7B2FF26DF75.description: Use words, phrases, and clauses to create cohesion within writing.

7BA3B27095B24BC49756D181E5C039E7.description: Develop clear claim(s) with specific evidence for a topic or text.

9411D89130974DA0B69C5BAC38A0D430.description: Identify evidence for claim(s) and counterclaim(s).

C2122DAC1B5249839DB4C620B39C6C37.description:
Create a writing organizational structure (e.g., introduce claims, distinguish supporting and opposing claims and relevant
evidence for each, provides conclusion) developing relationships among claim(s), reason, and evidence.

4AFEADC11D9E4B1682A8074C12418B47.description: Identify claim(s) from alternate or opposing claims(s) in writing.

E5E6D41494544BA081D526F53B2AEE59.description: Introduce claim(s) for an argument that reflects knowledge of the topic.

C04AC8AD27064785980D5B375A8BD6CE.description:
Write arguments to support claims in an analysis of substantive topics or texts, using valid reasoning and relevant and sufficient evidence.
a. Introduce precise claim(s), distinguish the claim(s) from alternate or opposing claims, and create an organization that establishes clear
relationships among claim(s), counterclaims, reasons, and evidence.
b. Develop claim(s) and counterclaims fairly, supplying evidence for each while pointing out the strengths and limitations of both in a manner
that anticipates the audience’s knowledge level and concerns.
c. Use words, phrases, and clauses to link the major sections of the text, create cohesion, and clarify the relationships between claim(s) and
reasons, between reasons and evidence, and between claim(s) and counterclaims.
d. Establish and maintain a formal style and objective tone while attending to the norms and conventions of the discipline in which they are
writing.
e. Provide a concluding statement or section that follows from and supports the argument presented.

0EDEC7A58E6A4443B3B529BF81041C0A.description: Use a variety of strategies to derive meaning from a variety print/non-print texts.

E298E2F371AD476780401F4C7AB71296.description:
Read or be read to a variety of texts including historical novels, periodicals, classical dramas or plays, poetry, novels
written by international authors, fiction and nonfiction novels.

FC0F63DFD7044F23BF805BE5917D8049.description: Use a variety of strategies to derive meaning from a variety print/non-print texts.

A64A58EF637F4AF3A461A553176DC824.description:
Read or be read to a variety of texts including historical novels, periodicals, classical dramas or plays, poetry, novels
written by international authors, fiction and nonfiction novels.

374DCFC9F34946DEBEEA43B6C008541A.description:
By the end of the year, proficiently and independently read and comprehend informational texts and nonfiction in a text complexity range
determined by qualitative and quantitative measures appropriate to grade 9. By the end of the year, proficiently and independently read and comprehend informational texts and nonfiction in a text complexity range
determined by qualitative and quantitative measures appropriate to grade 10.

740064261202400BAD4E6570C4F2B22F.description: Range of Reading and Level of Text Complexity

77A2EE962FE3473C98498A2D93C19392.description:
Analyze how seminal U.S. documents of historical and literary significance (e.g., Washington's Farewell Address, the
Gettysburg Address, Roosevelt's Four Freedoms speech, King's ―Letter from Birmingham Jail), address similar central ideas.

9AFBD56BA6A34DDFAB185912E9147D61.description:
Identify central ideas and concepts in seminal U.S. documents of historical and literary significance (e.g., Washington's
Farewell Address, the Gettysburg Address, Roosevelt's Four Freedoms speech, King's ―Letter from Birmingham Jail).

4D8F9884D94B4F24AFAD8B89A9B3F251.description: Analyze seminal/primary documents of historical and literary significance, including how they address related themes and concepts.

4945F4A1D9EF4093A1F15002779919D5.description: Assess the validity of the arguments across texts on related topics.

5B94C1E0C5B241D18737D37BA38D8EC0.description: Delineate the argument and specific claims in two or more texts on related topics.

FFE5E96EA2D74D86A4B971F9113B7BB3.description: Evaluate the argument/claims that the author makes to determine if the statements are true or false.

0C0A0E0D3F0145DDAD9FDE169CDE8B07.description: Delineate/trace the authors argument and specific claims.

C78219DD480F4ABA8071405548DF69A8.description: Identify claims and arguments made by the author.

CB2799278DBD4213B70A78E06A321770.description:
Delineate and evaluate the argument and specific claims in a text, assessing whether the reasoning is valid and the evidence is relevant and
sufficient; identify false statements and fallacious reasoning.

D55614DC98B84282A93F9B8D424B7096.description:
Analyze various accounts of a subject told in different mediums (e.g., a person's life story in both print and multimedia),
determining which details are emphasized in each account.

E8A7B66B10794F0484D8A6E54C049C36.description:
Analyze various accounts of a subject told in different mediums (e.g., a person’s life story in both print and multimedia), determining which
details are emphasized in each account.

3F87E2CA55C3444386969DE23836FF82.description: Develop and explain ideas for why authors made specific word choices within text.

D73132EF55F34178A34867D55C26DE12.description: Determine/identify the specific language/words that the author uses to advance the point of view or purpose.

024F525CA162493AA9B1FE65BB9E615F.description: Determine the author's point of view or purpose in a text.

FF57405FBE5149CEB885B04A25EEFE4E.description: Determine an author’s point of view or purpose in a text and analyze how an author uses rhetoric to advance that point of view or purpose.

95AD820DA5954324BECB827F45215210.description: Identify key sentences or paragraphs that support claims.

D6696437E8C245439B87DD579511C35C.description: Analyze in detail how an author's ideas or claims are developed.

109993B8B2A14F16B8927DB91C8C909A.description:
Analyze in detail how an author’s ideas or claims are developed and refined by particular sentences, paragraphs, or larger portions of a text
(e.g., a section or chapter).

810C646B3E21440C97174868ACBE4D3E.description: Analyze the use of figurative, connotative or technical terms on the meaning or tone of text.

B92C7C624D204DF0879206020CB4C47D.description:
Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text including figurative (i.e., metaphors, similes, and
idioms) and connotative meanings.

C50119568FA54BD2978CFC7A89F57262.description:
Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative, connotative, and technical meanings; analyze the
cumulative impact of specific word choices on meaning and tone.

1D0D817F01184FB68BD8764885BF7ED6.description: Analyze key points throughout a text to determine the organizational pattern or text structure.

33C5E50AD80B4FB9AD46292926095822.description:
Analyze how the author constructs an analysis or series of ideas or events, including the order in which the points are made, how they are
introduced and developed, and the connections that are drawn between them.

D53DD90DA0D3494A804155CCA4035106.description: Provide/create an objective summary of a text.

3F34373F37A94C43AE0629B0BEEF6204.description: Determine how key details support the development of the central idea of a text.

B52303B6C8164CFF8298A614422EEBA2.description: Determine how the central idea develops.

30B2C5C27F3F4E52AAF5E9346CB1635B.description: Determine the central idea of a text.

C1ADC5DF20EE43DB850DB9731D227736.description:
Determine a central idea of a text and analyze its development over the course of the text, including how it emerges and is shaped and refined
by specific details; provide an objective summary of the text.

02F7C645CCC244338323CA633F09AFE2.description: Determine which piece(s) of evidence provide the strongest support for inferences, conclusions, or summaries in a text.

9E1D3EFAA2044E65864FAFC7104BCB74.description: Use two or more pieces of evidence to support inferences, conclusions, or summaries.

CCB25CD1407948109A3870FDC2760F6C.description: Cite strong and thorough textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.

58F4438409A2445C92A683C748C0F965.description: Use strategies to derive meaning from a variety of texts and mediums.

26D4A61300F7431AB611B776CB5D0F29.description:
Read or be read to a variety of texts or adapted texts including historical novels, periodicals, classical dramas or plays,
poetry, novels written by international authors, fiction and nonfiction novels.

92422F5DBB4A424D9894918F8DAFCE55.description: Use strategies to derive meaning from a variety of texts and mediums.

4CB8405264AF40039B92DE354C5256CE.description:
Read or be read to a variety of texts or adapted texts including historical novels, periodicals, classical dramas or plays,
poetry, novels written by international authors, fiction and nonfiction novels.

88D51AA95F2E45949CE806C8382AD087.description:
By the end of the year, proficiently and independently read and comprehend literature, including stories, drama, and poetry, in a text
complexity range determined by qualitative and quantitative measures appropriate to grade 9. By the end of the year, proficiently and independently read and comprehend literature, including stories, drama, and poetry, in a text
complexity range determined by qualitative and quantitative measures appropriate to grade 10.

9256ECC497B44B5EA271825FAE6C4392.description: Range of Reading and Level of Text Complexity

DC6D0B3B602C4E6288ECB9AFC2161E84.description:
Analyze how an author draws on source material in a specific work (e.g., how Shakespeare treats a theme or topic from Ovid
or the Bible or how a later author draws on a play by Shakespeare.

F9C6AD63BE1446BDADEBC02123CC430A.description: Analyze how an author draws on and transforms source material in a specific work.

8521823F243C4B24B8E13AA8458A7134.description:
Analyze the representation of a subject or a key scene in two different artistic mediums, including what is absent in each
treatment.

25B82D8D3B3E4D63A97DB2514E3D50D1.description:
Analyze the representation of a subject or a key scene in two different artistic mediums, including what is emphasized or absent in each
treatment.

BB07DFE3C1F74B13840F66BE53E654C2.description: Compare and contrast works from different cultures with a common theme.

97F0461E26994EE19206BCDE50839E64.description: Analyze how points of view and/or cultural experiences are reflected in works of literature, drawing from a variety of literary texts.

CEECE034676C4CD09374DA1D0542E7F2.description:
Analyze how an author's choices concerning how to structure a text, order events within it (e.g., parallel plots), and
manipulate time (e.g., pacing, flashbacks) create such effects as mystery, tension, or surprise.

81D3DFB85F014D21AE6363C52EF07B94.description:
Analyze how an author’s choices concerning how to structure a text, order events within it, and manipulate time create such effects as
mystery, tension, or surprise.

4C5A07EB328D42ACBEA61CE8F03A77CA.description:
Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text including figurative (i.e., metaphors, similes, and
idioms) and connotative meanings.

710B0F52C21B4F79A05246F1EC4B7D94.description:
Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in the text, including figurative and connotative meanings; analyze the
cumulative impact of specific word choices on meaning and tone.

652891F8092445B59017882A8E7CA72C.description:
Delineate how a complex character develops over the course of a text, interacts with other characters, and advances the
plot or develops the theme.

CDEAE22E24BF47BAA9D98CC9C5B768DB.description: Identify character with multiple or conflicting motivations(i.e., a complex character).

6CE829CF7BA6474E8CE0A395BFCBFFB7.description:
Analyze how complex characters (e.g., those with multiple or conflicting motivations) develop over the course of a text, interact with other
characters, and advance the plot or develop the theme.

DAC55ED5A4FC4FA09764F554CC007ED8.description: Determine how key details support the development of the theme of an adapted grade appropriate text.

F81B5478DEFD4305BF6921538EAC9410.description: Determine the theme or central idea of an adapted grade appropriate text.

64A7D81E877744E98CFED078201568BB.description:
Determine a theme or central idea of a text and analyze in detail its development over the course of the text, including how it emerges and is
shaped and refined by specific details; provide an objective summary of the text.

27B8CB1FFCBD48BCA9C56BFC587E0700.description: Determine which piece(s) of evidence provide the strongest support for inferences, conclusions, or summaries of text.

FCD4DF5B244F4BA5B6FF300AF821830F.description:
Use two or more pieces of evidence to support inferences, conclusions, or summaries of the plot, purpose, or theme within
a text.

982DACE23A864E86B461A6615B4EFCA4.description: Cite strong and thorough textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
